docs.title: Elementary Chart library for Compose with KMP support!
docs.text: A sleek & lightweight charting library for Jetpack Compose, now with Kotlin Multiplatform (KMP) support! Built with ❤️ by @hi-manshu for developers who love charts.

docs.title: ✨ Features
docs.text:
• 🎨 Rich Chart Collection: 20+ chart types including Bar, Line, Pie, Radar, Candlestick, and more
  • 📱 Kotlin Multiplatform: Works on Android, iOS, Desktop, and Web
  • 🎯 Compose First: Built natively with Jetpack Compose
  • ⚡ Lightweight: Minimal dependencies, maximum performance
  • 🎨 Highly Customizable: Full control over colors, styles, and animations
  • 📊 Modern Design: Beautiful, Material Design-inspired charts
  • 🔧 Easy to Use: Simple, intuitive API

docs.title: 🚀 Quick Start
docs.text:
Get started with Charty in just a few minutes:

@Composable
fun MyChart() {
    BarChart(
        dataCollection = listOf(
            BarData(10f, "Jan"),
            BarData(20f, "Feb"),
            BarData(15f, "Mar")
        ),
        config = BarChartConfig(
            showAxis = true,
            showGridLines = true
        )
    )
}

Get Started →

docs.title: 📊 Chart Types
docs.text: Charty supports a wide variety of chart types:

docs.title: Bar Charts
docs.text:
• Bar Chart - Standard vertical bars
  • Horizontal Bar Chart - Horizontal orientation
  • Stacked Bar Chart - Multiple series stacked
  • Comparison Bar Chart - Side-by-side comparison
  • Lollipop Bar Chart - Lollipop style visualization
  • Waterfall Chart - Cumulative effect display
  • Wavy Chart - Bars with wavy tops
  • Bubble Bar Chart - Bars with bubble indicators
  • Mosaic Bar Chart - Mosaic pattern bars
  • Span Chart - Range-based visualization

docs.title: Line Charts
docs.text:
• Line Chart - Connect data points with lines
  • Area Chart - Filled area under the line
  • Multiline Chart - Multiple data series
  • Stacked Area Chart - Stacked filled areas

docs.title: Point Charts
docs.text:
• Point Chart - Scatter plot visualization
  • Bubble Chart - Size-based data points

docs.title: Other Charts
docs.text:
• Pie Chart - Circular sector representation
  • Radar Chart - Multi-axis visualization
  • Multiple Radar Chart - Compare multiple datasets
  • Candlestick Chart - Financial data visualization
  • Combo Chart - Combine multiple chart types
  • Block Bar - Block-style bars
  • Circular Progress - Circular progress indicator

docs.title: 🌍 Kotlin Multiplatform Support
docs.text:
Charty works seamlessly across multiple platforms:

Platform Status Android ✅ Fully Supported iOS ✅ Fully Supported Desktop (JVM) ✅ Fully Supported Web (JS) ✅ Fully Supported Web (Wasm) ✅ Fully Supported

docs.title: 🎨 Customization
docs.text:
Every chart in Charty is highly customizable:

  • Colors: Define your own color schemes
  • Styles: Customize line thickness, bar width, corner radius, etc.
  • Animations: Control animation duration and style
  • Axes: Configure axis labels, grid lines, and formatting
  • Labels: Full control over data labels and legends

Learn More About Customization →

docs.title: Charty Documentation
docs.text: This directory contains the MkDocs-based documentation for Charty.

docs.title: Install MkDocs and dependencies
docs.text:
pip install -r requirements.txt

Or install individually:

pip install mkdocs mkdocs-material pymdown-extensions

docs.title: Serve locally
docs.text:
Preview the documentation with live reload:

mkdocs serve

Then visit http://127.0.0.1:8000 in your browser.

docs.title: Build static site
docs.text:
Generate the static HTML documentation:

mkdocs build

The built site will be in the site/ directory.

docs.title: Deploying to GitHub Pages
docs.text:
Deploy to GitHub Pages:

mkdocs gh-deploy

This will build the documentation and push it to the gh-pages branch.

docs.title: Markdown Tips
docs.text:
• Use # for headers (# = h1, ## = h2, etc.)
  • Use triple backticks for code blocks with language specification
  • Use !!! note, !!! tip, !!! warning for admonitions
  • Link to other pages with [text](relative/path.md)

docs.title: Code Examples
docs.text:
Always specify the language for syntax highlighting:

```kotlin
fun example() {
    println("Hello")
}
```

pip3 install mkdocs

docs.title: Contributing to Charty
docs.text: Thank you for your interest in contributing to Charty! This document provides guidelines for contributing to the project.

docs.title: Code of Conduct
docs.text: Please read and follow our Code of Conduct.

docs.title: Reporting Bugs
docs.text:
If you find a bug, please create an issue on GitHub with:

  1. A clear, descriptive title
  2. Steps to reproduce the issue
  3. Expected vs actual behavior
  4. Screenshots (if applicable)
  5. Your environment (OS, Kotlin version, etc.)

docs.title: Suggesting Features
docs.text:
We welcome feature suggestions! Please create an issue with:

  1. A clear description of the feature
  2. Use case and benefits
  3. Proposed API (if applicable)
  4. Examples or mockups

docs.title: Pull Requests
docs.text:
1. Fork the repository
  2. Create a feature branch (git checkout -b feature/amazing-feature)
  3. Make your changes
  4. Add tests for new functionality
  5. Run tests and linting
  6. Commit your changes (git commit -m 'Add amazing feature')
  7. Push to the branch (git push origin feature/amazing-feature)
  8. Open a Pull Request

docs.title: Prerequisites

git clone https://github.com/hi-manshu/charty.git
cd charty

docs.title: Code Style
docs.text:
We follow Kotlin coding conventions. Run ktlint before committing:

./gradlew ktlintCheck
./gradlew ktlintFormat

docs.title: Chart Overview
docs.text: Charty provides a comprehensive collection of chart types for all your data visualization needs. This page provides an overview of all available charts.

docs.title: Bar Charts
docs.text: Bar charts are perfect for comparing discrete values across categories.

docs.title: Bar Chart
docs.text:
Standard vertical bar chart for comparing values.

BarChart(
    dataCollection = listOf(
        BarData(100f, "Jan"),
        BarData(200f, "Feb")
    )
)

docs.title: Horizontal Bar Chart
docs.text: Horizontal orientation for better label readability.

docs.title: Stacked Bar Chart
docs.text: Display multiple data series stacked on top of each other.

docs.title: Comparison Bar Chart
docs.text: Compare multiple series side-by-side.

docs.title: Lollipop Bar Chart
docs.text: Minimalist bar chart with lollipop-style markers.

docs.title: Waterfall Chart
docs.text: Show cumulative effect of sequential values.

docs.title: Wavy Chart
docs.text: Bars with decorative wavy tops.

docs.title: Bubble Bar Chart
docs.text: Bars with bubble indicators for additional data dimension.

docs.title: Mosaic Bar Chart
docs.text: Bars with mosaic/tile pattern styling.

docs.title: Span Chart
docs.text: Visualize ranges or time spans.

docs.title: Line Charts
docs.text: Line charts show trends and changes over continuous data.

Classic line chart connecting data points.

LineChart(
    dataCollection = listOf(
        LineData(10f, "Jan"),

docs.title: Multiline Chart
docs.text: Display multiple data series on the same chart.

docs.title: Stacked Area Chart
docs.text: Multiple data series stacked on top of each other.

docs.title: Bar Chart
docs.text: A standard vertical bar chart for comparing values across categories.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The Bar Chart is one of the most common chart types, perfect for comparing discrete values across different categories. Each bar represents a single data point, with the height corresponding to the value.

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text:
import androidx.compose.runtime.Composable
import androidx.compose.ui.Modifier
import com.himanshoe.charty.bar.BarChart
import com.himanshoe.charty.bar.data.BarData

@Composable
fun SimpleBarChart() {
    BarChart(
        dataCollection = listOf(
            BarData(yValue = 100f, xValue = "Jan"),
            BarData(yValue = 200f, xValue = "Feb"),
            BarData(yValue = 150f, xValue = "Mar"),
            BarData(yValue = 300f, xValue = "Apr"),
            BarData(yValue = 250f, xValue = "May")
        ),
        modifier = Modifier
            .fillMaxWidth()
            .height(300.dp)
    )
}

docs.title: BarData
docs.text:
data class BarData(
    val yValue: Float,      // The value (height of the bar)
    val xValue: String,     // The label on X-axis
    val color: Color? = null // Optional: custom color for this bar
)

Example: 

BarData(
    yValue = 100f,
    xValue = "January"
)

docs.title: BarChartConfig
docs.text:
Customize the appearance and behavior of your bar chart:

import com.himanshoe.charty.bar.config.BarChartConfig
import androidx.compose.ui.unit.dp

BarChart(
    dataCollection = data,
    config = BarChartConfig(
        barWidth = 40.dp,           // Width of each bar
        showAxis = true,             // Show X and Y axes
        showGridLines = true,        // Show background grid
        cornerRadius = 8.dp,         // Rounded corners on bars
        spacing = 16.dp              // Space between bars
    )
)

docs.title: Configuration Options
docs.text: Property Type Default Description barWidth Dp 40.dp Width of each bar showAxis Boolean true Show axes showGridLines Boolean false Show grid lines cornerRadius Dp 0.dp Corner radius for rounded bars spacing Dp 8.dp Space between bars animated Boolean true Enable animation animationDuration Int 800 Animation duration in ms

docs.title: Custom Colors
docs.text:
import androidx.compose.ui.graphics.Color

BarChart(
    dataCollection = data,
    color = Color(0xFF6200EE)
)

docs.title: Per-Bar Colors
docs.text:
BarChart(
    dataCollection = listOf(
        BarData(100f, "Jan", color = Color.Blue),
        BarData(200f, "Feb", color = Color.Green),
        BarData(150f, "Mar", color = Color.Red)
    )
)

docs.title: Styled Bars
docs.text:
BarChart(
    dataCollection = data,
    color = MaterialTheme.colorScheme.primary,
    config = BarChartConfig(
        barWidth = 50.dp,
        cornerRadius = 12.dp,
        showAxis = true,
        showGridLines = true
    )
)

docs.title: With Axis Configuration
docs.text:
import com.himanshoe.charty.common.config.AxisConfig

BarChart(
    dataCollection = data,
    config = BarChartConfig(
        barWidth = 40.dp,
        axisConfig = AxisConfig(
            showAxis = true,
            showAxisLabels = true,
            showGridLines = true,
            axisColor = Color.Gray,
            axisStroke = 2.dp
        )
    )
)

docs.title: Click Handling
docs.text:
Handle bar clicks to show details or navigate:

var selectedBar by remember { mutableStateOf<BarData?>(null) }

BarChart(
    dataCollection = data,
    onBarClick = { barData ->
        selectedBar = barData
        // Show dialog, navigate, etc.
    }
)

selectedBar?.let { bar ->
    Text("Selected: ${bar.xValue} - ${bar.yValue}")
}

docs.title: Dynamic Updates
docs.text:
Update chart data dynamically:

var data by remember {
    mutableStateOf(
        listOf(

docs.title: 1. Appropriate Bar Count
docs.text:
Don't overcrowd the chart. For mobile, keep it to 5-10 bars for readability:

// Good
BarChart(dataCollection = data.take(8))

// Avoid
BarChart(dataCollection = veryLargeDataset) // 50+ bars

docs.title: 2. Consistent Sizing
docs.text:
Always specify chart dimensions:

BarChart(
    dataCollection = data,
    modifier = Modifier
        .fillMaxWidth()
        .height(300.dp) // Always specify height
)

docs.title: 3. Meaningful Labels
docs.text:
Use clear, concise labels:

// Good
BarData(100f, "Jan")

// Avoid
BarData(100f, "January 2025 Sales Data")

docs.title: 4. Color Accessibility
docs.text:
Ensure sufficient contrast:

val isDark = isSystemInDarkTheme()
val barColor = if (isDark) Color(0xFF90CAF9) else Color(0xFF1976D2)

BarChart(
    dataCollection = data,
    color = barColor
)

docs.title: Real-Time Data Updates
docs.text:
@Composable
fun RealTimeChart() {
    var data by remember {
        mutableStateOf(
            listOf(BarData(0f, "Start"))
        )
    }

    LaunchedEffect(Unit) {
        while (true) {
            delay(1000)
            val newValue = Random.nextFloat() * 100
            data = (data + BarData(newValue, "")).takeLast(10)
        }
    }

    BarChart(dataCollection = data)
}

docs.title: Interactive Charts
docs.text:
@Composable
fun InteractiveChart() {
    var selectedData by remember { mutableStateOf<BarData?>(null) }
    var showDialog by remember { mutableStateOf(false) }

    BarChart(
        dataCollection = data,
        onBarClick = { barData ->
            selectedData = barData
            showDialog = true
        }
    )

    if (showDialog && selectedData != null) {
        AlertDialog(
            onDismissRequest = { showDialog = false },
            title = { Text(selectedData!!.xValue) },
            text = { Text("Value: ${selectedData!!.yValue}") },
            confirmButton = {
                Button(onClick = { showDialog = false }) {
                    Text("OK")
                }
            }
        )
    }
}

@Composable
fun AdaptiveChart() {
    val isDark = isSystemInDarkTheme()
    val chartColor = if (isDark) Color(0xFF90CAF9) else Color(0xFF1976D2)
    val axisColor = if (isDark) Color.White else Color.Black

    BarChart(
        dataCollection = data,
        color = chartColor,
        config = BarChartConfig(
            axisConfig = AxisConfig(
                axisColor = axisColor.copy(alpha = 0.5f)
            )
        )
    )
}

docs.title: Adaptive Sizing
docs.text:
@Composable
fun ResponsiveChart() {
    BoxWithConstraints(modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize()) {
        val chartHeight = maxHeight * 0.4f
        val isWide = maxWidth > 600.dp

        BarChart(
            dataCollection = data,
            modifier = Modifier
                .fillMaxWidth()
                .height(chartHeight),
            config = BarChartConfig(
                barWidth = if (isWide) 50.dp else 30.dp
            )
        )
    }
}

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: Learn how to configure and customize your charts in Charty.

docs.title: Configuration Overview
docs.text: Every chart in Charty can be configured using its respective configuration class. These configuration objects allow you to customize the appearance and behavior of your charts.

docs.title: Axis Configuration
docs.text:
Most charts support axis configuration through AxisConfig:

import com.himanshoe.charty.common.config.AxisConfig

val axisConfig = AxisConfig(
    showAxis = true,              // Show X and Y axes
    showGridLines = true,         // Show grid lines
    showAxisLabels = true,        // Show axis labels
    axisColor = Color.Gray,       // Color of axes
    axisStroke = 2.dp             // Stroke width of axes
)

docs.title: Chart Defaults
docs.text:
Access default configurations through ChartDefaults:

import com.himanshoe.charty.common.config.ChartDefaults

// Use default colors
val defaultColor = ChartDefaults.color

// Use default axis config
val defaultAxisConfig = ChartDefaults.axisConfig

docs.title: Bar Chart Configuration
docs.text:
import com.himanshoe.charty.bar.config.BarChartConfig

BarChart(
    dataCollection = data,
    config = BarChartConfig(
        barWidth = 40.dp,          // Width of each bar
        showAxis = true,            // Show axes
        showGridLines = true,       // Show grid lines
        axisConfig = AxisConfig(
            showAxis = true,
            axisColor = Color.Gray
        )
    )
)

docs.title: Line Chart Configuration
docs.text:
import com.himanshoe.charty.line.config.LineChartConfig

LineChart(
    dataCollection = data,
    config = LineChartConfig(
        lineWidth = 3.dp,          // Width of the line
        showAxis = true,            // Show axes
        showGridLines = true,       // Show grid lines
        showPoints = true,          // Show data points
        pointRadius = 5.dp,         // Size of data points
        isCurved = true,            // Curve the line
        axisConfig = AxisConfig(
            showAxis = true,
            axisColor = Color.Gray
        )
    )
)

docs.title: Pie Chart Configuration
docs.text:
import com.himanshoe.charty.pie.config.PieChartConfig

PieChart(
    dataCollection = data,
    config = PieChartConfig(
        showSliceLabels = true,     // Show labels on slices
        showPercentage = true,      // Show percentage values
        donut = false,              // Make it a donut chart
        donutRadius = 0.6f,         // Inner radius (if donut)
        animated = true,            // Enable animation
        animationDuration = 800     // Animation duration in ms
    )
)

docs.title: Radar Chart Configuration
docs.text:
import com.himanshoe.charty.radar.config.RadarChartConfig

RadarChart(
    dataCollection = data,
    config = RadarChartConfig(
        showAxis = true,            // Show axes
        showLabels = true,          // Show labels
        showGridLines = true,       // Show grid lines
        numberOfLevels = 5,         // Number of concentric levels
        strokeWidth = 2.dp          // Width of the radar line
    )
)

docs.title: Candlestick Chart Configuration
docs.text:
import com.himanshoe.charty.candlestick.config.CandlestickChartConfig

CandlestickChart(
    dataCollection = data,
    config = CandlestickChartConfig(
        candleWidth = 20.dp,        // Width of candles
        showWicks = true,           // Show high/low wicks
        upColor = Color.Green,      // Color for bullish candles
        downColor = Color.Red,      // Color for bearish candles
        showAxis = true,
        showGridLines = true
    )
)

docs.title: Single Color
docs.text:
Set a single color for the entire chart:

BarChart(
    dataCollection = data,
    color = Color(0xFF6200EE)
)

docs.title: Custom Color Scheme
docs.text:
Use Charty's color system:

import com.himanshoe.charty.color.ChartyColor
import com.himanshoe.charty.color.ChartyColors

// Use predefined color schemes
BarChart(
    dataCollection = data,
    color = ChartyColors.Blue
)

// Or create custom colors
val customColor = ChartyColor(
    primary = Color(0xFF6200EE),
    secondary = Color(0xFF03DAC5)
)

docs.title: Multi-Color Charts
docs.text:
For charts with multiple series or slices:

// Pie chart with different colors per slice
PieChart(
    dataCollection = listOf(
        PieData(30f, "A", color = Color.Blue),
        PieData(45f, "B", color = Color.Green),
        PieData(25f, "C", color = Color.Red)
    )
)

docs.title: Enable/Disable Animations
docs.text:
import com.himanshoe.charty.common.animation.AnimationHelper

BarChart(
    dataCollection = data,
    config = BarChartConfig(
        animated = true,             // Enable animation
        animationDuration = 1000     // Duration in milliseconds
    )
)

docs.title: Custom Animation Specs
docs.text:
import androidx.compose.animation.core.tween
import androidx.compose.animation.core.Spring
import androidx.compose.animation.core.spring

// Smooth tween animation
val tweenSpec = tween<Float>(durationMillis = 1000)

// Spring animation
val springSpec = spring<Float>(
    dampingRatio = Spring.DampingRatioMediumBouncy,
    stiffness = Spring.StiffnessLow
)

docs.title: Adaptive Sizing
docs.text:
Use modifiers to make charts responsive:

@Composable
fun ResponsiveChart() {
    BoxWithConstraints(modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize()) {
        val chartHeight = maxHeight * 0.4f
        val barWidth = maxWidth / 20

        BarChart(
            dataCollection = data,
            modifier = Modifier
                .fillMaxWidth()
                .height(chartHeight),
            config = BarChartConfig(
                barWidth = barWidth
            )
        )
    }
}

docs.title: Orientation Support
docs.text:
Handle different screen orientations:

@Composable
fun OrientationAwareChart() {
    val configuration = LocalConfiguration.current
    val isLandscape = configuration.orientation == Configuration.ORIENTATION_LANDSCAPE

    BarChart(
        dataCollection = data,
        modifier = Modifier
            .fillMaxWidth()
            .height(if (isLandscape) 400.dp else 300.dp)
    )
}

docs.title: Content Descriptions
docs.text:
Add content descriptions for accessibility:

import androidx.compose.ui.semantics.contentDescription
import androidx.compose.ui.semantics.semantics

BarChart(
    dataCollection = data,
    modifier = Modifier.semantics {
        contentDescription = "Bar chart showing monthly sales data"
    }
)

docs.title: Large Datasets
docs.text:
For large datasets, consider:

  1. Data Sampling: Show a subset of data points
  2. Lazy Loading: Load data on demand
  3. Caching: Cache computed values
@Composable
fun OptimizedChart(largeDataset: List<BarData>) {
    // Sample data for better performance
    val sampledData = remember(largeDataset) {
        if (largeDataset.size > 50) {
            largeDataset.filterIndexed { index, _ -> index % 2 == 0 }
        } else {
            largeDataset
        }
    }

    BarChart(dataCollection = sampledData)
}

docs.title: Material Theme Colors
docs.text:
Integrate with Material Theme:

import androidx.compose.material3.MaterialTheme

@Composable
fun ThemedChart() {
    BarChart(
        dataCollection = data,
        color = MaterialTheme.colorScheme.primary,
        config = BarChartConfig(
            axisConfig = AxisConfig(
                axisColor = MaterialTheme.colorScheme.onSurface.copy(alpha = 0.5f)
            )
        )
    )
}

docs.title: Dark Mode Support
docs.text:
Handle dark/light themes automatically:

import androidx.compose.foundation.isSystemInDarkTheme

@Composable
fun AdaptiveChart() {
    val isDark = isSystemInDarkTheme()
    val axisColor = if (isDark) Color.White else Color.Black

    BarChart(
        dataCollection = data,
        config = BarChartConfig(
            axisConfig = AxisConfig(
                axisColor = axisColor.copy(alpha = 0.5f)
            )
        )
    )
}

docs.title: Custom Grid Lines
docs.text:
BarChart(
    dataCollection = data,
    config = BarChartConfig(
        showGridLines = true,
        axisConfig = AxisConfig(
            showGridLines = true,
            gridLineColor = Color.Gray.copy(alpha = 0.2f),
            gridLineWidth = 1.dp
        )
    )
)

docs.title: Combined Configurations
docs.text:
BarChart(
    dataCollection = data,
    color = MaterialTheme.colorScheme.primary,
    modifier = Modifier
        .fillMaxWidth()
        .height(300.dp)
        .padding(16.dp),
    config = BarChartConfig(
        barWidth = 40.dp,
        showAxis = true,
        showGridLines = true,
        animated = true,
        animationDuration = 800,
        axisConfig = AxisConfig(
            showAxis = true,
            showAxisLabels = true,
            showGridLines = true,
            axisColor = MaterialTheme.colorScheme.onSurface.copy(alpha = 0.3f),
            axisStroke = 2.dp
        )
    )
)

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: Get started with Charty in your project by adding the dependency.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Kotlin 2.2.21 or higher
  • Compose Multiplatform 1.9.3 or higher
  • Android minSdk 24 (for Android projects)

docs.title: Kotlin Multiplatform
docs.text:
Add Charty to your common source set in your build.gradle.kts:

kotlin {
    sourceSets {
        commonMain.dependencies {
            implementation("com.himanshoe:charty:<latest-version>")
        }
    }
}

docs.title: Android Project
docs.text:
Add Charty to your app-level build.gradle.kts:

dependencies {
    implementation("com.himanshoe:charty:<latest-version>")
}

Latest Version

Check the latest version on Maven Central

docs.title: Version Catalog (recommended)
docs.text:
If you're using Gradle version catalogs, add this to your libs.versions.toml:

[versions]
charty = "<latest-version>"

[libraries]
charty = { module = "com.himanshoe:charty", version.ref = "charty" }

Then in your build.gradle.kts:

kotlin {
    sourceSets {
        commonMain.dependencies {
            implementation(libs.charty)
        }
    }
}

docs.title: Android
docs.text:
No additional configuration needed! Charty works out of the box with Jetpack Compose.

Make sure your build.gradle.kts has Compose enabled:

android {
    buildFeatures {
        compose = true
    }
    composeOptions {
        kotlinCompilerExtensionVersion = "<compose-compiler-version>"
    }
}

docs.title: iOS
docs.text:
Charty works with Compose Multiplatform for iOS. Ensure you have the iOS framework configured:

kotlin {
    listOf(
        iosArm64(),
        iosSimulatorArm64()
    ).forEach { iosTarget ->
        iosTarget.binaries.framework {
            baseName = "YourApp"
            isStatic = true
        }
    }
}

docs.title: Desktop (JVM)
docs.text:
Charty works with Compose for Desktop:

kotlin {
    jvm {
        withJava()
    }
}

docs.title: Web (JS/Wasm)
docs.text:
For web targets:

kotlin {
    js {
        browser()
    }

    // or for WebAssembly
    wasmJs {
        browser()
    }
}

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text:
Create a simple test to verify Charty is installed correctly:

import androidx.compose.runtime.Composable
import com.himanshoe.charty.bar.BarChart
import com.himanshoe.charty.bar.data.BarData

@Composable
fun TestChart() {
    BarChart(
        dataCollection = listOf(
            BarData(10f, "A"),
            BarData(20f, "B"),
            BarData(15f, "C")
        )
    )
}

If this compiles and runs without errors, you're all set! 🎉

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: Learn how to create your first chart with Charty in just a few minutes!

docs.title: Your First Chart
docs.text:
Let's create a simple bar chart to visualize some data:

import androidx.compose.foundation.layout.*
import androidx.compose.runtime.Composable
import androidx.compose.ui.Modifier
import androidx.compose.ui.unit.dp
import com.himanshoe.charty.bar.BarChart
import com.himanshoe.charty.bar.data.BarData
import com.himanshoe.charty.bar.config.BarChartConfig

@Composable
fun MyFirstChart() {
    Column(
        modifier = Modifier
            .fillMaxSize()
            .padding(16.dp)
    ) {
        BarChart(
            dataCollection = listOf(
                BarData(yValue = 100f, xValue = "Jan"),
                BarData(yValue = 200f, xValue = "Feb"),
                BarData(yValue = 150f, xValue = "Mar"),
                BarData(yValue = 300f, xValue = "Apr"),
                BarData(yValue = 250f, xValue = "May")
            ),
            modifier = Modifier
                .fillMaxWidth()
                .height(300.dp)
        )
    }
}

That's it! You've created your first chart. 🎉

docs.title: Data Models
docs.text:
Every chart in Charty uses a data model. For bar charts, we use BarData:

BarData(
    yValue = 100f,  // The value (height of the bar)
    xValue = "Jan"  // The label (X-axis label)
)

Different chart types have different data models:

  • LineData for line charts
  • PieData for pie charts
  • PointData for point/bubble charts
  • RadarData for radar charts
  • etc.

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
Most charts accept a configuration object to customize their appearance:

BarChart(
    dataCollection = myData,
    config = BarChartConfig(
        showAxis = true,
        showGridLines = true,
        barWidth = 40.dp
    )
)

docs.title: Modifiers
docs.text:
Like all Compose components, charts accept modifiers:

BarChart(
    dataCollection = myData,
    modifier = Modifier
        .fillMaxWidth()
        .height(300.dp)
        .padding(16.dp)
)

docs.title: Loading State
docs.text:
Handle loading states with conditional rendering:

@Composable
fun ChartWithLoading(data: List<BarData>?) {
    Box(
        modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
        contentAlignment = Alignment.Center
    ) {
        when {
            data == null -> CircularProgressIndicator()
            data.isEmpty() -> Text("No data available")
            else -> BarChart(dataCollection = data)
        }
    }
}

docs.title: Dynamic Data
docs.text:
Update charts with state:

@Composable
fun DynamicChart() {
    var data by remember {
        mutableStateOf(
            listOf(
                BarData(100f, "A"),
                BarData(200f, "B")
            )
        )
    }

    Column {
        BarChart(dataCollection = data)

        Button(onClick = {
            data = data + BarData(150f, "C")
        }) {
            Text("Add Data")
        }
    }
}

docs.title: Custom Colors
docs.text:
Customize colors for better branding:

import com.himanshoe.charty.common.config.AxisConfig
import com.himanshoe.charty.common.config.ChartDefaults

BarChart(
    dataCollection = myData,
    color = Color(0xFF6200EE),  // Primary color
    config = BarChartConfig(
        axisConfig = AxisConfig(
            showAxis = true,
            showGridLines = true,
            axisColor = Color.Gray
        )
    )
)

PieChart(

import com.himanshoe.charty.point.PointChart
import com.himanshoe.charty.point.data.PointData

PointChart(
    dataCollection = listOf(
        PointData(10f, 20f),
        PointData(15f, 35f),
        PointData(20f, 25f)

docs.title: 1. Size Your Charts
docs.text:
Always specify chart dimensions:

BarChart(
    dataCollection = data,
    modifier = Modifier
        .fillMaxWidth()
        .height(300.dp)  // Specify height
)

docs.title: 2. Handle Empty Data
docs.text:
Check for empty data before rendering:

if (data.isNotEmpty()) {
    BarChart(dataCollection = data)
} else {
    Text("No data to display")
}

docs.title: 3. Use Appropriate Chart Types
docs.text:
Choose the right chart for your data:

  • Bar/Column: Comparing discrete values
  • Line: Showing trends over time
  • Pie: Showing proportions of a whole
  • Scatter: Showing relationships between variables
  • Radar: Comparing multiple variables

docs.title: 4. Keep It Simple
docs.text:
Don't overcomplicate your charts:

// Good - Clear and simple
BarChart(
    dataCollection = data,
    config = BarChartConfig(showAxis = true)
)

// Avoid - Too many customizations can be overwhelming
